How many faculties are permanently eliminated, arise, and attain the fruit of stream-entry?
Answer: No faculties are permanently eliminated.
Seven faculties are eliminated and arise.
One is eliminated but not arisen, one arises but is not eliminated, and one attains the fruit of stream-entry.
As for the seven faculties that are eliminated and arise,
the seven refer to the faculties of mind, equanimity, and the five beginning with faith.
Elimination refers to those seven being included in the uninterrupted path.
Arising refers to those seven being included in the path of liberation.
Moreover, elimination refers to what is included in the path of approach.
Arising refers to what is included in the path of fruition.
Moreover, elimination refers to what is included in the category of the receptivity to the cognition of the doctrine with regard to the path.
Arising refers to what is included in the category of the cognition of the doctrine with regard to the path.

Arising refers to what arises together with the faculty of understanding.

Arising refers to what is included in the path of cultivation.

it refers to the faculty of understanding what has not been understood.
As for one arising but not being eliminated,
it refers to the faculty of understanding.

it is explained as attaining the fruit of stream-entry.

there are no faculties that are permanently eliminated, and seven faculties are eliminated and produced to attain the fruit of once-returning.

Eliminated refers to those included in the seven uninterrupted paths.
Produced refers to those included in the seven liberation paths.
Moreover, eliminated refers to those included in the path of approach.
Produced refers to those included in the path of fruition.

there are no faculties that are permanently eliminated, and eight faculties are eliminated and produced to attain the fruit of once-returning.
The eight faculties that are eliminated and produced are
the same as the previous seven plus the faculty of having known.
The meanings of elimination and production are as explained above.
